how do i push my current repo to github

Here are the general steps to push your current repository to GitHub:

1. First, make sure you have a GitHub account and have created a new repository on GitHub.

2. In your local repository, add the remote GitHub repository URL using the following command:

   ```
   git remote add origin <remote repository URL>
   ```

3. Next, stage your changes using the following command:

   ```
   git add .
   ```

4. Commit your changes with a commit message using the following command:

   ```
   git commit -m "commit message"
   ```

5. Finally, push your changes to the remote repository using the following command:

   ```
   git push -u origin master
   ```

This will push your current repository

github cli

GitHub CLI is a command-line tool that allows you to interact with GitHub repositories and perform various tasks such as creating, cloning, and managing repositories, opening and closing issues, reviewing pull requests, and more. It is available for Windows, macOS, and Linux operating systems. With GitHub CLI, you can perform most of the tasks that you would normally do on the GitHub website, but from the command line.

cli github

GitHub CLI is a command-line tool that allows you to interact with GitHub from your terminal. With GitHub CLI, you can perform many of the same actions available on the GitHub website, such as creating and managing repositories, opening and closing issues, and reviewing pull requests. 

To get started with GitHub CLI, you'll need to install it on your computer. You can download the latest version of GitHub CLI from the official GitHub CLI website. Once you have installed GitHub CLI, you can use the `gh` command to interact with GitHub from your terminal. 

Some common commands you can use with GitHub CLI include:

- `gh repo create`: Creates a new repository on GitHub.
- `gh issue list`: Lists all the issues in a repository.
